questions.question: Which of the following macroscopic features is most characteristic of Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis?

options.A: Continuous inflammation from the rectum extending proximally
options.B: Erythematous, granular mucosa with superficial ulcerations
options.C: Deep, punched-out ulcers with transmural inflammation
options.D: Thickened bowel wall and mesenteric fat wrapping

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Thickened bowel wall and mesenteric fat wrapping Explanation: Thickened Bowel Wall and Mesenteric Fat Wrapping are typical features of Crohn’s disease. The bowel wall becomes thickened due to transmural inflammation, and there is often “creeping fat” around the bowel. Macroscopic features of UC and Crohn’s: Feature Ulcerative Colitis Crohn's Disease Location Rectum and colon, continuous; does not involve small intestine. Any part of the GI tract; often the terminal ileum, colon; can involve small bowel and upper GI tract. Extent Continuous inflammation; no skip lesions. Patchy inflammation with skip lesions between affected areas. Appearance Erythematous, granular mucosa; superficial ulcers. Deep, serpiginous ulcers, especially on the mesenteric side. Wall Involvement Mucosa and submucosa only. Transmural inflammation through all bowel layers. Strictures Rare. Common due to transmural inflammation and fibrosis. Fistulas Rare, usually perianal. Common, including between bowel loops and adjacent organs. Fat Wrapping Absent. Present; "creeping fat" around the bowel wall. Additional Features - Thickened bowel wall; thickened mesentery with enlarged lymph nodes. Images Microscopic features of ulcerative colitis and crohn’s: Feature Ulcerative Colitis Crohn's Disease Inflammation Limited to mucosa and submucosa. Transmural, affecting all bowel wall layers. Transmural Lymphoid Aggregates Inflammatory Cells Predominantly polymorphonuclear leukocytes in lamina propria. Chronic inflammation with mononuclear cells, edema, hyperemia, and lymphangiectasia. Crypt Abscesses May be present, but not unique. Can be present. Goblet Cells Mucin depletion may occur. Not specifically noted. Granulomas Absent. Present in 60%-70% of cases; non-caseating. Lymphoid Aggregates Absent unless deep ulceration is present. Present, especially in non-ulcerated areas. Crypt Architecture Often distorted with irregular branching. Not specifically noted. Images

options.C: Diverting Loop Ileostomy with Colonic Lavage

questions.question: A 38-year-old male presents with severe abdominal distension and diarrhea. His vitals show a heart rate of 125 beats/min, fever of 38.9°C, and a white blood cell count of 13,800/microL. A radiograph reveals colonic dilation of 7 cm. Which of the following additional findings would not confirm the diagnosis of toxic megacolon?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Anemia Explanation: Anemia is one of the systemic signs considered in the diagnostic criteria but does not fulfill the additional systemic toxicity criteria (which are altered sensorium, dehydration, electrolyte disturbances, or hypotension). Thus, anemia alone would not be sufficient to confirm toxic megacolon when assessing the systemic toxicity criteria. Pathogenesis and Risk Factors of Toxic Megacolon Pathogenesis Colonic inflammation increases inducible nitric oxide synthase production, inhibiting smooth muscle tone and contributing to colonic dilatation. Risk Factors Ulcerative colitis (most common) Infectious colitis: particularly Clostridium difficile infection Crohn's disease Hypokalemia Antimotility agents Opiates, Anticholinergics, Antidepressants Abrupt cessation of glucocorticoids Barium enemas; Colonoscopy/bowel preparation Sulfasalazine and 5-ASA compounds can precipitate toxic megacolon Diagnosis and Evaluation of Toxic Megacolon Diagnosis Criteria Radiographic Evidence: Colonic dilation (diameter >6 cm) PLUS at least three of the following: Fever >38ºC Heart rate >120 beats/min Neutrophilic leukocytosis >10,500/microL Anemia PLUS at least one of the following: Dehydration Altered sensorium (Option B) Electrolyte disturbances (Option D) Hypotension (Option C) Differential Diagnosis Congenital megacolon (Hirschsprung's disease). Acquired megacolon (chronic constipation). Chagas megacolon. Colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie syndrome). Diffuse gastrointestinal dysmotility. Acute colonic obstruction from diverticulitis, volvulus, tumors. Reference: Sabiston’s textbook of surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1352 https://www.uptodate.com/contents/toxic-megac olon?search=toxic%20megacolon&source=search_result&selectedTitle=1~42&usage_type=default&display_rank =1

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient diagnosed with mild Crohn's disease affecting the ileocecal region presents to your clinic. The patient has mild symptoms with no significant systemic involvement. What is the most appropriate first-line drug to prescribe for this patient to induce remission in mild Crohn's disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Budesonide Explanation: Budesonide is a first-line treatment for inducing remission in mild to moderate Crohn's disease, especially when the disease is localized in the ileocecal region. It is a corticosteroid with a high first-pass metabolism, resulting in fewer systemic side effects than corticosteroids like prednisone. Category Mild Crohn's Disease Moderate to Severe Crohn's Disease Induction Therapy First-line : Budesonide (preferred for ileocecal disease) (Option D) or aminosalicylates (e.g., mesalamine). Prednisone for those who do not respond to budesonide. (Option A) Alternative : Enteral nutrition. First-line : Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone for short term) or biologics Anti-TNF agents (Infliximab, Adalimumab) (Option C) Anti-integrin therapy (Vedolizumab) Anti-interleukin therapy (Ustekinumab) Combination therapy : Anti-TNF agents plus immunomodulators (Azathioprine, 6-MP) (Option B) Maintenance Therapy First-line : Continue aminosalicylates if effective. Alternative : Thiopurines (azathioprine, 6-MP) for patients intolerant to aminosalicylates. Anti-TNF monotherapy : Long-term for maintaining remission. Combination therapy : Anti-TNF agents with immunomodulators (for severe cases or history of nonresponse to biologics). Continue anti-integrin or anti-interleukin agents for those induced by these therapies Monitoring Regular follow-up to monitor symptoms and inflammation. Ileocolonoscopy 6-12 months post-remission. Drug level monitoring and fecal calprotectin to assess mucosal healing. Management of complex fistulising Crohn's disease Management Drug therapy With Abscess: Prompt surgical drainage with seton placement. Initiate anti-TNF therapy post-drainage. Without Abscess: EUA with seton placement and anti-TNF therapy combined with antibiotics. Removal of setons based on clinical response and imaging. Consider switching biologics or further surgical intervention if fistula does not heal. Initial Therapy: Anti-TNF agents + antibiotics (metronidazole or ciprofloxacin). Alternative/ Adjunctive: Thiopurines (azathioprine, 6-MP), other biologics (vedolizumab, ustekinumab, upadacitinib). Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1330. https://www.uptodate.com/contents/ overview-of-the-medical-management-of-mild-low-risk-crohn-disease-in-adults?search=crohn&source=search_res ult&selectedTitle=1~150&usage_type=default&display_rank=1 https://www.uptodate.com/contents/medical-mana gement-of-moderate-to-severe-crohn-disease-in-adults?search=crohn&topicRef=4069&source=see_link https://ww w.uptodate.com/contents/perianal-crohn-disease?search=fistulizing%20Crohn%27s&source=search_result&select edTitle=2~150&usage_type=default&display_rank=2

questions.question: A patient with chronic ulcerative colitis who had undergone total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis has come to the department complaining of diarrhoea, abdominal pain, fever and malaise. On examination, hematochezia is noted. What is the first line of treatment here?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Antibiotic therapy Explanation: The clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of pouchitis. The first line of treatment for pouchitis is antibiotic therapy. Definition: Pouchitis is an inflammatory condition affecting the ileal pouch and continent ileostomy reservoirs. It occurs in 30% to 55% of cases. Etiology: The actual etiology is unknown. It may be due to fecal stasis in the pouch, but emptying studies are not confirmatory. Clinical features: Diarrhea Hematochezia Fever Pain abdomen Malaise Investigation and diagnosis: Endoscopy and biopsy Management : First line: Antibiotic therapy using metronidazole +/- ciprofloxacin . Oral preparations or enemas can be given. In chronic pouchitis, ongoing suppressive therapy is to be given. Salicylate and corticosteroids can also be used. In case of refractory disease, normal flora in the intestine is reintroduced with the help of probiotics (Option C) and/ or an elemental diet . Biological agents (Option B) like TNF I (infliximab, vedolizumab, ustekinumab) Pouch excision (Option D) is done in cases of chronic pouchitis. Reference: Schwartz Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 1278. Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1326.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male with a long-standing history of chronic inflammatory bowel disease presents for routine follow-up. He undergoes a colonoscopy, during which suspicious lesions are identified. A biopsy confirms the presence of malignancy. Which of the following types of cancer is more commonly associated with Crohn's disease than with ulcerative colitis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Small intestine carcinoma Explanation: Small intestine cancers are more prone to Crohn’s disease than ulcerative colitis. Small bowel adenocarcinoma is a rare complication associated with Crohn’s disease. This is because the small bowel (ileum) is the most common part of the intestine affected by Crohn’s disease. Risk factors of carcinoma in ulcerative colitis: Pancolonic disease Duration (Long-standing disease) Dysplasias Left-sided colitis Primary sclerosing cholangitis Hereditary colon cancer Young age Features of colitis-associated carcinoma: Age group >30 years Due to prolonged colitis Develops from colitis → dysplasia → carcinoma Dysplasia seen here is flat dysplasia Pancolonic disease: multicentric and infiltrative Increased mortality Endoscopic removal or colonoscopy is done Interval cancers are possible Colon carcinoma (Option A) is a complication of both Crohn’s and ulcerative colitis with equal occurrences. Cholangiocarcinoma (Option C) is associated with ulcerative colitis. The risk factor here is primary sclerosing cholangitis. Gastric cancer (Option D) is not associated with Ulcerative colitis or Crohn’s disease. It is rather associated with chronic peptic ulcers . Reference: Schwartz Principles of Surgery, 11th edition, Page 1283. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7988828/

questions.question: Which of the following would be a differentiating feature of Colitis-associated colon carcinoma (CAC) from sporadic colon cancer?

options.A: Sporadic colon cancer develops due to chronic inflammation and dysplasia
options.C: CAC is more common after the age of 30
options.D: Sporadic colon cancer is associated with young individuals

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) CAC is more common after the age of 30 years Explanation: Colitis-associated colon carcinoma (CAC) is more common after 30 years and sporadic colon cancer is most common in the 8th decade. Colitis-associated colon cancer Sporadic colon cancer Age group >30 years Due to prolonged colitis Develops from colitis to dysplasia to carcinoma Dysplasia seen here is flat dysplasia Pancolonic disease: multicentric and infiltrative Increased mortality (Option B) Endoscopic removal or colonoscopy is done Interval cancers are possible Age group > 50 years Most common in 8th decade (Option D) Most common site is the sigmoid colon, with left-side predominance Usually arises from an adenomatous polyp (Option A) Reference: Schwartz Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Pages 1282, 1283. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1367. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37663937/

questions.question: A 58-year-old male comes to the hospital complaining of intermittent pain in the anal region and intermittent diarrhea for 6 months. On examination, he was found to have complex perianal fistulas bilaterally, with skin tags, as shown in the image. His blood investigations reveal anemia. What could be the possible diagnosis leading to this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Crohn’s disease of anorectum Explanation: Crohn’s disease of the anorectum presents with multiple complex fistulae mostly bilateral and with purplish skin tags that give an “elephant ear" appearance. Clinical features: Bilaterally located complex anal fistula Elephant ear type large skin tags-edematous and purplish. Broad-based anal fissures away from the midline Anorectal abscess, which may rupture and lead to fistulae Ulceration Investigations: Digital rectal examination Proctoscopy Proctosigmoidoscopy MRI may be

questions.question: A patient with a history of ulcerative colitis (UC) has undergone a total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (TPA + IPAA) as part of their treatment. Which of the following is not a possible complication of the procedure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Peritonitis Explanation: Peritonitis is a complication of inflammatory bowel disease and not of the surgery. It is caused due to abscesses or fistulae in the intestine due to the disease. Complications of TPA+IPAA: Pouchitis: most common postoperative complication Pouch failure Risk of adhesions or small bowel obstruction Pouch-related fistula (pouch vaginal) Pelvic sepsis Strictures Anastomosis and pouch line leaks Crohn’s disease de novo Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10455305/ Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1355.

questions.question: Which of the following procedures is the definitive management of Ulcerative colitis?

options.B: Total Proctocolectomy with Ileal Pouch-Anal Anastomosis (TPA+IPAA)
options.C: Total Proctocolectomy with mucosectomy with hand-sewn IPAA
options.D: Total abdominal colectomy with very low Hartmann closure with end ileostomy

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Total Proctocolectomy with Ileal Pouch - Anal Anastomosis Explanation: Total Proctocolectomy with Ileal Pouch-Anal Anastomosis (TPA + IPAA) Indications: Definitive treatment for ulcerative colitis, especially in young patients. Eliminates risk of colorectal cancer and colitis-related symptoms. Pre-operative Considerations: Covering loop ileostomy is performed to protect the new pouch and aid healing. Typically done in two stages: Proctocolectomy and ileal pouch creation. Closure of the ileostomy after pouch healing. Proctocolectomy (First Stage) Remove the colon and rectum. Preserve the anal canal. ↓ Ileal Pouch Creation Create a J-shaped ileal pouch from a segment of the ileum. Connect the pouch to the anal canal (ileal pouch-anal anastomosis). ↓ Anastomosis and Ileostomy Anastomose the J-pouch to the anal canal. Perform a covering loop ileostomy to divert intestinal contents and protect the pouch. ↓ Post-operative Imaging Conduct a Gastrografin contrast enema to confirm the integrity and healing of the pouch. ↓ Closure of Ileostomy (Second Stage) Close the ileostomy once pouch healing is confirmed through imaging. ↓ Post-surgical Outcomes Monitor for adjustment to stool frequency and management of minor issues like urgency or fecal incontinence, which usually improve over time. Pouch Variations: J-pouch is most commonly used; other designs like S and W pouches are less favored due to functional outcomes. TPC + End Ileostomy (Option A) is preferred for older patients and patients with fecal incontinence. TPC + mucosectomy with hand-sewn IPAA (Option C) is a procedure done in case of the presence of rectal dysplasia. Total abdominal colectomy with very low Hartmann closure with end ileostomy (Option D) is done in more debilitating cases and those who can’t tolerate long duration of surgery. The rectum is spared here.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with a history of chronic abdominal pain, frequent bloody diarrhea, and an urgent need to defecate. Colonoscopy reveals continuous inflammation starting from the rectum and extending through the colon. Despite receiving the highest doses of medical therapy, the symptoms have worsened. Which of the following would not be considered an indication for surgery in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Enteroenteric fistula Explanation: Surgery is the preferred choice of treatment in case of complications of Crohn’s disease such as tenesmus, multiple bowel movements, fulminant colitis, failure of maximum medical management and those with poor quality of life as a result of poor nutritional status. However, enteroenteric fistulas do not require surgery unless they are accompanied by notable symptoms, such as obstruction or significant discomfort. Abdominal pain caused by obstruction is also regarded as an indication for surgery. Indications of surgery in IBD: Ulcerative colitis Crohn’s disease: Failure of maximum medical therapy (Option A) Poor quality of life due to tenesmus, urgency, and low body weight. Multiple bowel movements (Option B) , poor nutritional status (Option D) , and weak physical health. Growth retardation in children or adolescents; Fulminant colitis (Option C) . Some of these cases may also have toxic megacolon. Severe colitis leads to chronic ileus and a dilated colon, both leading to an increased risk of perforation. Significant GI bleeding Associated sclerosing cholangitis Presence of colonic dysplasia or cancer in colonoscopic surveillance (chronic UC > 8 years) Perianal disease not responding to treatment. Severe extra-intestinal disease Children with failure to thrive Symptoms of obstruction secondary to fibrostenosing Crohn's disease Perforated Crohn’s disease with associated abscess or fistula Severe abdominal pain with obstruction Cancer or dysplasia Isolated terminal ileal disease Recurrent disease Incidental finding of Crohn’s during an appendectomy Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 1349, 1350 Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1331, 1332.

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis has achieved clinical remission with a biologic agent. Which of the following drugs is used in the maintenance therapy for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Adalimumab Explanation: Adalimumab is an anti-TNF agent used in the maintenance therapy of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It helps maintain remission after the initial response. Aspect Mild to Moderate UC Moderate to Severe UC Goals of Therapy Induce and maintain clinical remission. Achieve and maintain glucocorticoid-free remission, prevent relapse. Initial Treatment 5-ASA compounds (e.g., mesalamine, sulfasalazine) or topical corticosteroids. (Options A & C) 5-ASA compounds, corticosteroids (Option D) , or biologics (e.g., anti-TNF agents, vedolizumab). Maintenance Therapy 5-ASA compounds; consider thiopurines for non-responders or relapsers. Biologics (e.g., anti-TNF agents- infliximab, adalimumab (Option B) ; vedolizumab), thiopurines, or small molecules (e.g., JAK inhibitors). Lab Monitoring CBC, liver tests every 3-4 months; electrolytes and renal function annually. Endoscopic Evaluation Not routinely required unless symptoms persist. Colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy every 6 months, or based on clinical need. Inflammatory Markers CRP and fecal calprotectin every 3-4 months if used. Relapse Management Optimize dosage, consider switching therapies if necessary. Evaluate for co-existing conditions and adherence. Specific Therapies Thiopurines: Consider if non-responsive to 5-ASA. Anti-TNF Agents Vedolizumab Ustekinumab Mirikizumab JAK Inhibitors (Tofacitinib, Upadacitinib) S1P Receptor Modulators (Ozanimod, Etrasimod) Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 1348, 1349. https://www.uptodate.com/contents/medic al-management-of-low-risk-adult-patients-with-mild-to-moderate-ulcerative-colitis?search=Medical%20manageme nt%20of%20Ulcerative%20colitis&source=search_result&selectedTitle=3~150&usage_type=default&display_ran k=3

questions.question: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a low rectal tumor and requires bowel diversion. The surgeon is considering the type of stoma to be created. Which of the following indications best matches the need for an ileostomy rather than a colostomy?

options.A: To relieve bowel obstruction when resection is not feasible.
options.B: To protect a distal anastomosis after low anterior resection.
options.C: To manage inflammatory diseases with severe perianal disease.
options.D: Permanent fecal diversion following total colectomy

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Permanent fecal diversion following total colectomy Explanation: Permanent fecal diversion following total colectomy is one of the major indications for Ileostomy. An end ileostomy is indicated following total colectomy for conditions such as Rectal carcinoma or familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). This results in a permanent stoma, where the ileum is brought to the surface, and the patient manages the stoma for life. The absence of the colon necessitates this approach, making it specific to conditions involving the entire colon removal. A colostomy can be used to relieve obstruction when resection isn't possible , such as in cases of obstructing rectal cancer or sigmoid volvulus. It helps divert stool away from the obstruction site. (Option A) A colostomy is commonly used to protect a distal anastomosis , especially after rectal surgery, by diverting fecal flow and allowing the anastomosis to heal without the risk of contamination from fecal material. (Option B) While ileostomy may sometimes be used in Crohn's and other inflammatory diseases, colostomy can also be indicated, particularly when the disease is localized to the colon and perianal regions . It helps manage fecal diversion in severe cases, allowing perianal lesions to heal. (Option C) Feature Ileostomy Colostomy Location Typically located in the right iliac fossa Typically located in the left iliac fossa Stool Consistency Usually results in liquid or semi-liquid stool Produces a more formed stool Spout Ileostomy is usually spouted Colostomy is usually flush Use To defunction the rest of the bowel in order to protect a distal anastomosis To evacuate stool from the body if the entire colon has been removed (such as in colorectal cancer, IBD) To relieve bowel obstruction To protect a distal anastomosis or allow healing away from the faecal flow Following resection when anastomosis is unsafe or not possible To relieve obstruction when resection is not feasible To reduce disease activity (e.g. Crohn’s disease) To allow alternative bowel control (incontinence) Fluid and electrolyte problems More likely Less likely Appliances Requires bags that often need to be emptied frequently due to the liquid consistency of the stool Uses appliances that may be changed as needed, depending on the type of colostomy and stool consistency Image

questions.question: A 39-year-old male with a 12-year history of ulcerative colitis presents with worsening symptoms despite maximum medical therapy. He experiences >10 bowel movements per day, urgency, tenesmus, and significant weight loss. Biopsies show high-grade dysplasia. The surgical team plans a total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA). What is the primary goal of the planned surgery for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Curative Explanation: The primary goal of the planned surgery, which is a total proctocolectomy with Ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA), is to cure ulcerative colitis. IPAA has become the most popular procedure for Ulcerative colitis not responding to medical therapy as well as for patients requiring colectomy for the presence of dysplasia. It significantly improves the patient's quality of life and effectively cures the colonic manifestation of ulcerative colitis I . Palliative surgery (Option A) relieves symptoms without addressing the underlying cause. While it may be used to manage severe symptoms in some cases, the primary goal of a proctocolectomy in ulcerative colitis is to remove the diseased bowel and provide a cure, not just symptom relief I . Achieving remission (Option B) refers to controlling the symptoms and inflammation with medication . Surgery, in this case, is intended to cure the disease by removing the entire diseased colon and rectum, not just to put the disease into remission I Maintenance (Option D) typically refers to ongoing medical therapy to manage the disease. In the context of high-grade dysplasia in ulcerative colitis, the surgery is performed with a curative intent to prevent cancer. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 1349,1350,1352. Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1323, 1325.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding ulcerative colitis is correct? in all patients with ulcerative colitis. alone. and evidence of systemic toxicity.

options.A: Backwash ileitis, where there is secondary inflammation in the terminal ileum, is a common finding
options.B: Extraintestinal manifestations such as arthritis are more likely to occur in patients with proctitis
options.C: 8 bloody stools per day and associated joint pain are classified as moderate ulcerative colitis.
options.D: Fulminant ulcerative colitis is characterized by >10 bowel movements daily, continuous bleeding,

questions.explanation: continuous bleeding, and evidence of systemic toxicity. Correct Answer: D) Fulminant ulcerative colitis is characterized by >10 bowel movements daily, continuous bleeding, and evidence of systemic toxicity. Explanation: Fulminant ulcerative colitis is associated with >10 bowel movements daily, fever, tachycardia, continuous bleeding, anemia, hypoalbuminemia, abdominal tenderness and distension , the need for blood transfusion and, in the most severe cases, progressive colonic dilation ( toxic megacolon ). This is a very significant finding, suggestive of disintegrative colitis, and an indication for emergency surgery if colonic perforation is to be avoided. Backwash ileitis is a secondary inflammation in the terminal ileum, seen in some patients with pancolitis but not all ulcerative colitis patients. It involves retrograde inflammation extending 2–3 cm into the terminal ileum from the colon. Risk factors include extensive colitis and primary sclerosing cholangitis. Biopsies help distinguish backwash ileitis from Crohn's disease-related ileitis. (Option A) If inflammation is confined to the rectum (proctitis) , there are usually no systemic symptoms, and extra-alimentary manifestations are rare. The main symptoms are rectal bleeding, tenesmus and mucous discharge. (Option B) According to the severity classification, a patient with > 6 bloody stools per day and evidence of systemic illness, such as joint pain, would be classified as having severe ulcerative colitis , not moderate. (Option C) Truelove and Witts Severity Classification for Ulcerative Colitis: Severity Stool Frequency Systemic Symptoms and signs Mild <4 stools/day No systemic signs of toxicity Moderate >4 stools/day Fever, abdominal pain, Elevated ESR, CRP Severe >6 stools/day Fever, tachycardia, anemia, systemic illness, hypoalbuminuria, Elevated ESR, CRP Fulminant >10 stools/day Continuous bleeding, fever, tachycardia, abdominal tenderness & distension, “Toxic megacolon” (progressive colonic dilation, an indication for emergency surgery) in severe cases Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1319, 1327 https://www.uptodate.com/co ntents/endoscopic-diagnosis-of-inflammatory-bowel-disease-in-adults?search=backwash%20ileitis&source=search _result&selectedTitle=1%7E8&usage_type=default&display_rank=1#H3285139932

questions.question: A 38-year-old patient with a history of chronic diarrhea and rectal bleeding undergoes a barium enema for evaluation. The radiological image shows changes in the colonic mucosa. Based on the findings of the barium enema, which of the following radiological features is most indicative of Ulcerative colitis (UC)?

options.A: Narrowed, constricted colon with a "hose pipe" appearance
options.B: Multiple deep ulcers with surrounding inflammation
options.C: Discontinuous patches of inflammation with normal segments in between

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Narrowed, constricted colon with a "hose pipe" appearance Explanation: Ulcerative colitis is characterized by the loss of haustrations and narrowing of the colon, which can appear like a "hose pipe" on a barium enema. Clinical Features of Ulcerative Colitis (UC): Chronic Diarrhea: M/c symptom.

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents with persistent and worsening chronic diarrhea, rectal bleeding, and abdominal pain for the past several months. An endoscopic examination reveals continuous mucosal inflammation starting at the rectum and extending proximally. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of ulcerative colitis (UC) and helps differentiate it from Crohn's disease?

options.B: Continuous inflammation starting from the rectum
options.D: Presence of granulomas in the mucosal layer

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Continuous inflammation starting from the rectum Explanation: Ulcerative colitis is characterized by inflammation that begins at the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner without skip lesions. This differentiates it from Crohn’s disease, which often presents with patchy inflammation and skip lesions. Ulcerative Colitis (UC) UC is an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) characterized by chronic inflammation primarily affecting the mucosal layer of the colon. Unlike Crohn's disease, which can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract and involves deeper bowel layers, UC is limited to the colon and involves only the mucosal layer. Contributing factors Defective mucin production: Mucosal immunological reactions Autoimmune factors (Cytotoxic T cells, anticolon antibodies) HLA DR2 association Family history Cow's milk allergy Stress and lifestyle associations Protective factors Appendicectomy Smoking Sites of involvement UC is confined to the large intestine. Always involves the rectum; extends proximally continuously. Extent of involvement: Proctitis/Proctosigmoiditis (Limited to the rectum and sigmoid colon) Left-Sided Colitis Pancolitis (Entire colon) Colonoscopy Findings Continuous inflammation from the dentate line of the rectum and extends proximally. Initially, mucosa appears erythematous, granular, or roughened; it worsens over time. Ulcers are long, serpentine, covered in fibrin, with a "bear claw" appearance. Significant bleeding can occur due to ulcer erosion into blood vessels. Microscopic Findings Inflammation limited to the mucosal layer Polymorphonuclear leukocytes in lamina propria. Depletion of mucin in goblet cells. Crypt abscesses contain inflammatory cells within Lieberkühn crypts. No granulomas, deep fissural ulcers, or transmural lymphoid aggregates. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 1344-1346 SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 883 Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1318, 1319.

questions.question: Which extraintestinal manifestation is most commonly associated with Crohn's disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Erythema nodosum Explanation: The most common extraintestinal manifestation of Crohn’s disease is skin lesions. Specifically, erythema nodosum and pyoderma gangrenosum are the most common skin conditions. Erythema nodosum is characterised by painful, red nodules usually located on the shins. Extra intestinal manifestations can occur in about 30% of Crohn's patients. 1. Skin Erythema nodosum Erythema multiforme Pyoderma gangrenosum 2. Eyes Iritis Uveitis Conjunctivitis 3. Blood Anemia Thrombocytosis Phlebothrombosis Arterial thrombosis 4. Joints Peripheral Arthritis Ankylosing spondylitis Sacroiliitis 5. Liver Non-specific Hepatitis Primary sclerosing cholangitis Cholesterol gallstones 6. Kidney Nephrotic syndrome (Rare) 7. Urological Stones (Most common type: Oxalate stones) Ureteral obstruction Entero-vesical fistula 8. Pancreas Pancreatitis (Rare) 9. Amyloidosis (Rare) Most common cutaneous manifestation of IBD - Erythema Nodosum Erythema Nodosum Most responsive for Rx of bowel disease Persistence of Erythema Nodosum - Indicates inadequate control of IBD Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1261 Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1329. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 857.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient with a history of long-standing Crohn's disease presents for a follow-up examination. An abdominal X-ray with barium contrast is performed to evaluate the current state of the small bowel. Based on the barium radiographic image provided, which of the following signs is depicted below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) String Sign of Kantor Explanation: String Sign of Kantor is associated with long-standing Crohn’s disease . It is characterised by multiple filling defects seen in barium studies due to kinking and fibrosis of the bowel, especially the terminal ileum. Laboratory Tests: Serologic Markers: pANCA: Helps predict inflammatory bowel disease development. ASCA: Differentiates Crohn’s disease from ulcerative colitis and predicts surgery needs. Noninvasive Markers: Fecal Lactoferrin & Fecal Calprotectin: Specific to intestinal inflammation; correlates with CTE findings. Radiology: CT enterography (CTE) and magnetic resonance

questions.question: A 34-year-old female with a known diagnosis of Crohn's disease presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, weight loss, and intermittent diarrhea. Imaging studies reveal significant inflammation and strictures in the gastrointestinal tract. Which part of the gastrointestinal tract is most commonly affected by Crohn's disease, leading to ulcers and strictures?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ileum Explanation: The ileum is the most common site affected by Crohn's disease, where complications such as enterocutaneous fistulas, enterovesical fistulas, ulcers, strictures, and carcinoma frequently occur. Crohn's disease is a chronic, transmural inflammatory condition of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, most commonly affecting the ileum. It presents with insidious onset, chronic diarrhoea (with loose bowel movements, rarely containing blood, pus, or mucus.), intermittent colicky abdominal pain (often in the right lower quadrant- mimics appendicitis), systemic symptoms like weight loss, and low-grade fever. The disease can affect any part of the GI tract (mouth to anus) but most frequently involves the small intestine and colon with discontinuous "skip areas." Complications: Complication Description Obstruction Acute inflammation, oedema, chronic fibrotic lesions Perforation This leads to fistulas, localised abscesses, and rarely generalised peritonitis Toxic Megacolon Colonic dilation, abdominal tenderness, fever, leukocytosis Bleeding Chronic, indolent, possible massive bleeding with duodenal involvement Cancer Risk Cancer Type Risk Factors and Characteristics Small Intestine Chronic mucosal inflammation, higher relative risk M/c site in the small intestine: Ileum Colon Elevated risk with prolonged disease, dysplasia precursor Small Bowel Adenocarcinoma Aggressive, with high extracellular mucin Extraintestinal Squamous cell carcinoma (vulva, anal canal), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, increased with immunomodulators Perianal Disease: Affects about 25% of Crohn’s patients, often preceding intestinal symptoms. Common presentations include fissures, fistulas, strictures, or abscesses. Multiple, chronic perianal fistulas should raise suspicion for Crohn’s disease. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 1260-1262 Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1327,1328 SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 856, 857

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. A resection of the terminal ileum is performed, and the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of this disease?

options.A: Continuous mucosal lesions and crypt abscesses
options.C: Superficial ulceration and loss of haustrations

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cobblestone appearance and transmural inflammation Explanation: The given image of the respected terminal ileum shows a Cobblestone appearance along with longitudinal ulcerations , characteristic of Crohn’s disease. Cobblestone appearance is a hallmark of Crohn's disease, resulting from deep ulcerations and intervening areas of normal mucosa. Transmural inflammation , which affects all layers of the bowel wall, is a characteristic microscopic finding in Crohn's disease. Continuous mucosal lesions and crypt abscesses (Option A) are more characteristic of Ulcerative Colitis (UC). questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and recent weight loss. On examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant, and a colonoscopy revealed patchy inflammation in the terminal ileum with skip lesions. Which of the following combinations of risk factors and etiological factors is most consistent with the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) NOD2/CARD15 gene mutation, smoking Explanation: The given presentation of chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and recent weight loss, with tenderness in the right lower quadrant, along with patchy inflammation in the terminal ileum with skip lesions on colonoscopy, is consistent with Crohn’s disease. The NOD2/CARD15 gene mutation on chromosome 16 is strongly associated with Crohn's disease. Smoking worsens the condition. Etiology and Risk Factors in Crohn’s Disease vs. Ulcerative Colitis Feature Crohn’s Disease Ulcerative Colitis Genetic Factors NOD2/CARD15 gene mutation on chromosome 16 (Option A) HLA-DR2 association (Option B) Smoking Increases risk Protective effect, lowers risk (Option C) Diet Highly refined food, food additives, particularly preservatives Westernized diet, red meat, milk allergy (Option D) . Less common in vegetarians. Autoimmune Factors Bacterial dysbiosis with aggressive T cell immune response to specific components of intestinal microbes Cytotoxic T lymphocytes against Colonic epithelial cells and the presence of anticolon antibodies. (Option C) Appendectomy No clear association (Option B) Protective Environmental Triggers Mycobacterium infection, high levels of sanitation in childhood Stress, personality disorders (Option D) Family History Strong familial association, 10% of first-degree relatives and 50% of monozygotic twins. Familial tendency present, less frequent Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 855, 883. Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1327 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5759609/

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman undergoes an emergency ileostomy following bowel obstruction. Two weeks postoperatively, she presents with increased pain and swelling around the stoma site. On examination, a bulge is noted adjacent to the stoma. The stoma itself appears healthy, with no signs of necrosis or ischemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Parastomal Hernia Explanation: A parastomal hernia occurs when the abdominal contents protrude through the defect in the abdominal wall created for the stoma. It typically presents as a bulge around the stoma and can lead to discomfort, pain, and cosmetic concerns I . This complication is more common with ileostomies due to the increased intra-abdominal pressure and the nature of the bowel segment used. Stoma Complications Complications Description Key Characteristics Stoma Ischemia Lack of blood supply causing stoma discoloration and necrosis Occurs early post-op (within days), Discolored Stoma Prolapse (Option D) Excessive protrusion of the stoma through the abdominal wall Protrusion, more common in loop stomas Stoma Retraction (Option B) Stoma sinks below skin level; often leads to poor appliance fit and skin irritation Concave surface, skin irritation Parastomal Hernia (Option C) Herniation of abdominal contents through the stoma opening Bulging adjacent to the stoma, discomfort Stoma Stenosis (Option A) Narrowing of stoma, leading to obstruction Narrowed opening, obstruction symptoms Skin Irritation Irritation or breakdown of skin around the stoma due to appliance use Poor appliance fitting, leakage Bleeding May occur due to trauma or mucosal irritation Trauma, irritation Fistulation Formation of abnormal connections between the stoma and other organs or skin Infection Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1314, 1373. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 902.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male patient undergoes emergency abdominal surgery for a perforated sigmoid diverticulitis with peritonitis. The surgeon decides to create a stoma as part of the management plan. Which of the following stomas is most appropriate for diverting fecal content and allowing distal bowel healing while planning for potential future reconnection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Loop ileostomy Explanation: A loop ileostomy is commonly used to divert fecal content in emergency situations and allows for the distal bowel to heal, making it ideal for temporary diversion. It provides an easy way to reverse the stoma when the patient is stable and reconnection is feasible . Types of Stomas Type Description Common Uses Reversibility End Colostomy (Option A) Single opening from the proximal bowel. Often permanent. Used when the distal bowel is removed or left in place, e.g., Hartmann's procedure Often permanent Loop Ileostomy (Option B) Loop of bowel is brought to the surface, and an incision is made Temporary diversion, especially in emergencies, and easily reversible Usually temporary Double-barrel Colostomy (Option C) Two stomas are created: one for faecal output and one for mucus discharge Rarely used; can be for cases requiring both resection and exteriorization, offering mucous fistula Can be temporary Permanent Ileostomy (Option D) Terminal ileum is brought to the surface after a colectomy Used when reconnection is not planned, often after total proctocolectomy for conditions like FAP Permanent
